Enrollment applications are open for Fall 2020 CS370: Adaptive Teaching Methods in Computer Science!
CS370 Application: tinyurl.com/ydd2ly86

The two lectures to choose from are as follows:
Tuesdays 1:00pm-3:00pm in Jacobs or online if necessary
Wednesdays 2:00pm-4:00pm in TBD or online if necessary

Applications are open for enrolling in CS370 for the Fall 2020 semester! We will be reviewing applications on Friday, June 20th and June 27th. Then every week thereafter. Once you're accepted we will manually enroll you in the course with no further action necessary on your part. After Friday June 27th I will be enrolling accepted students in the course every week until the course is full or all demand is met.

What is CS370?
CS370 is our course on adaptive teaching in CS which meets the mandatory course requirement for TAs--though it can be taken as early as the semester following your completion of one of the following: Data8, CS10, CS61A, or EE16A. The course is a 3-unit graduate course on teaching that is available for a letter-grade or P/NP basis.
This course is highly interactive with everyone participating in designing materials and resources to help you as a tutor, mentor, and TA—also, most of the material translates effectively to industry and academia.

CS370 emphasizes adapting your teaching techniques based on student learning styles and academic performance to further increase student mastery. It's also equity-oriented which means you learn how to apply different instructional methods and assessments to address psychosocial factors for multiple student backgrounds and preferred learning strategies.

Unlike CS375/EE375 this course is 3 units and thus requires tutoring each week (1-3 hours per week depending on your potential course staff roles; most non-TAs complete 2-3 hours per week). This is often one of the favorite parts of CS370. The difference in time commitment between 375 and 370 is about an hour per week, and the majority of students find it to be worthwhile, though the choice is entirely yours.
If interested in a more detailed description, please read it on the application website.

Thank you and please spread the word to those who might be interested!
PS Email me at cthunn@berkeley.edu with questions; just put CS370 in the subject line. Thanks again!
